title: 113_s2597
content: The "Promise Zone Job Creation Act of 2014" establishes Promise Zones under the Internal Revenue Code, providing employment credits and expensing of Promise Zone property. The "Promise Zone Job Creation Act of 2014" establishes Promise Zones as areas nominated by local governments or Indian Tribes, with a population not exceeding 200,000, and designated by the Secretaries of Housing and Urban Development and Agriculture. The Promise Zone Job Creation Act of 2014 allows for the designation of up to 20 Promise Zones, with 6 designated for rural areas. The Secretaries of Housing and Urban Development and Agriculture must jointly designate these areas before January 1, 2017. The Promise Zone Job Creation Act of 2014 allows for the designation of 20 Promise Zones, with 6 for rural areas. Designations take effect upon agreement execution and last for 10 years or until revoked. The Promise Zone Job Creation Act of 2014 allows for the designation of Promise Zones, with specific criteria for nomination and limitations on designations. Areas already designated as Promise Zones will be considered under the new designation process. The Promise Zone Job Creation Act of 2014 outlines the criteria for nominating areas as Promise Zones. The application must demonstrate eligibility and commitment to implementing a competitiveness plan. Data on economic conditions must be provided to the Secretaries of Housing and Urban Development and Agriculture. Accuracy of information furnished is crucial for designation. Eligibility criteria for Promise Zones include a competitiveness plan addressing investment, job creation, education, leveraging economic strengths, collaboration, regional economic growth, affordable housing, and public safety. Selection criteria are based on nominated areas' eligibility. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and the Secretary of Agriculture will designate Promise Zones based on competitiveness plans, unemployment rates, poverty rates, vacancy rates, crime rates, household income, home-ownership, labor force participation, educational attainment, and other criteria determined by the Secretaries. The Secretaries of Housing and Urban Development and Agriculture can establish minimum standards for unemployment and poverty levels required for Promise Zone designation. "SEC. 1400V-2. PROMISE ZONE EMPLOYMENT CREDIT." The Promise Zone employment credit is determined based on the applicable percentage of qualified wages paid to employees. The applicable percentage is 20% for certain qualified wages and 10% for others. Qualified wages are those paid to employees who are qualified zone employees. The Promise Zone employment credit is based on qualified wages paid to qualified zone employees or qualified resident employees. The maximum amount of qualified wages per employee per year is $15,000. Qualified wages do not include wages used for the work opportunity credit, and the $15,000 limit is reduced by wages used for the work opportunity credit. The term 'wages' for determining credit under section 51 is defined in section 1397(a). A qualified employee is either a qualified zone employee or a qualified resident employee, with specific criteria for each. The term 'qualified resident employee' refers to an employee whose principal place of abode is within a Promise Zone, but most of their services for the employer are not performed within the Promise Zone. Certain individuals, as defined in section 1396(d)(2), are not eligible for this designation. ``(e) Special Rules.--Rules similar to section 1397 apply here. ``(f) Taxpayer Reporting.--No credit without required information for evaluation of program effectiveness. "SEC. 1400V-3. EXPENSING OF PROMISE ZONE PROPERTY." "A taxpayer can choose to expense the cost of Promise Zone property, allowing it as a deduction in the year the property is placed in service. Promise Zone property includes tangible property with a recovery period of 20 years or less, water utility property, and certain computer software." The taxpayer can elect to expense Promise Zone property, which includes tangible property with a recovery period of 20 years or less, water utility property, and certain computer software. This property must be acquired for use in a trade or business, placed in service in a Promise Zone, and not subject to section 168(g). The election process is similar to section 179 rules, and Promise Zone property is not treated as section 179 property for tax purposes. The Promise Zone property is not considered section 179 property. Rules similar to section 179 apply, and taxpayer reporting is required for evaluation. Conforming amendments include a Promise Zone employment credit under section 1400V-2. The Promise Zone employment credit under section 1400V-2 is added to the table of parts for subchapter Y of chapter 1 of the Code. The Promise Zone employment credit under section 1400V-2 applies to taxable years ending after December 31, 2014.
